author: @robertnitsch9519
text: I noticed, too, that ChatGPT is really good at writing and altering code according to your inputs. It shocked me as well. On the other hand there are weird gaps in its abilities, for example it cannot write poems in German with rhymes. It has no understanding of what a rhyme is. It pretends to know, but then fails miserably each time to produce any rhymes. (In English that's not an issue by the way.) These gaps remind you that it has just been trained on an unfathomable amount of data. In the end you ask yourself, what is intelligence after all? It seems you can create convincingly intelligent systems by feeding them with huge datasets. If sufficient conceivable conversations have been memorized, then it will appear to be intelligent. For me it's uncomfortable how far that brute-force approach gets you... because ChatGPT in many cases really appears to be smart.

author: @badviper2059
text: Tom Scott has got to be one of the most relatable, human feeling educational youtubers I watch. Perhaps it's the way he describes his own feelings about things without tainting the actual facts with those feelings. I've had this exact same gnawing uncertainty about the future for years now, as I'm sure many have, but had never placed it to a question like "Where on the sigmoid curve are we?" Stuck in a weird place of not wanting to be a "boomer" who can't accept new things, but not wanting to feel like the world I know is going to fundamentally change either. The mark of the older millennial I suppose, or any younger-middle-aged person perhaps. It comes in waves. "Oh no everything's going to change! Humans won't have any reason to exist anymore!" to "Nah... It can't change that much can it? Everything's going to be fine." On the one hand, it's nice to know I'm not one of the only people who gets this gut twisting feeling, and on the other, it really really sucks to be sent back to the former side of the wave by watching this. xp

author: @Cornan1980
text: I was a nerd in the 90s and have spent the last 25-ish years working in IT and computer repair in one form or another. The older I get and the farther we get along into "The Information Age" the more I think that the Butlerian Jihad from Dune may have been on to something.

text: When Tom says "I'm going to be out of a job soon", I'd be really curious to hear him describe what he thinks his job is what it would mean for an ML algorithm to do it.

author: @ShukenFlash
text: I've played around with ChatGPT a few times and got that same sort of, slightly unsettling feeling. I'm glad you put in the thought to figure out why because it's been bugging me too. I think it's more or less the same thing, this almost uncanny valley feeling like we might be on the edge of a tectonic shift and I'm not sure if I'm ready for that huge, sudden change just yet.

author: @andraslibal
text: It feels like it when you ask it to do something you are only slightly competent in and it has a lot of data and that was done many times before.If you ask something particular that has not been done many times and where you are competent you can see how much it is just a data filter.

author: @JamplayJeff
text: I feel the same sense of dread. Like you, I try to convince myself that people won't be replaced but enhanced, but I'm not so sure anymore. The people developing these models are not going to stop regardless of the consequences and I agree that no one knows or cares where this is going.

author: @barrycarter7274
text: As someone who works in software. I honestly think we're towards the beginning of that upward curve. The reason I say this is that most of these tools were absolutely terrible/didn't exist just before the pandemic started. And now look where we are. The pandemic meant lots of nerds had extra time to figure out these complex problems and as a community a lot of problems were resolved.

author: @interflashz
text: In terms of applications of machine learning we are probably somewhere near the napster point, but in terms of capability and quality of the networks I feel like we are closer to midway on the sigmoid. The insane level of progress in the last few years has mostly come from increasing the size of the models and training data by orders of magnitude over a really short period of time. So much so that I feel like we've already caught up to what's possible computationally, training wise. So progress in model size will probably slow down to the rate of computer performance increases soon.

author: @LindaB-j6k
text: I'm convinced that successfully growing old is about the ability to see so much change and not let it freak you out so much that you can't move forward with it (or even ahead of it).

author: @bleuflamenco
text: Up until around the year 2000, I had stored away every single email I had ever sent or received.  Spam wasn't a thing, nor did I really ever get any automated emails.  So it was 99.9% personal messages between friends, albeit usually friends I only met and knew online.  Nowadays of course my email is just a daily flood of garbage.

author: @Japanese_Made_Easy_Podcast
text: You're not wrong. This is the beginning of a major shift. As a person with no coding skills, I was not able to get ChatGPT to come up with the correct code to make a very simple, but functional indicator for a program called MT4. It said it could code in the required language, but no luck. So, I think it takes a human with coding skills, to be able to evaluate the output and makes fixes as you did.

author: @madeinsydl
text: How well this has aged. Well done Tom

author: @tortysoft
text: I grew up with Valves... I remember and lived through the Transistor upheaval that grew in to the Integrated Circuit. I was trained how to adjust the contacts of a Relay at Post Office Telecoms. I then joined the BBC and worked with Video Tape recorders - quadruplex two inch wide tapes. They too were replaced - by one inch tapes, then half inch cassettes then Digital cassette - then data cards. I have been made technologically redundant at least seven times and I kept having to move on. I wrote programming articles for the Archimedes computer thirty years ago, demo progs were stuck on the magazine covers. Then the Internet came. You know the rest of the story, you tell it well.I'm not forced by Long Covid to retire, but when my brain fog allows, I am learning the IoT, python coding, RPi and esp8266/32 that sort of thing. I can't teach any more, but... I could make a fe videos. I already have a podcast - Torty Talks...

text: Actually, I think before Napster, it was journalism. My father was a newspaper guy and he was retiring right around that time and there were so many free news sites that newspapers were starting to crash. People were cancelling subscriptions. Newspapers were already struggling at that point and the internet ended up wiping out quite a few of them.

At least that's where we are in 2023.

author: @Rik77
text: Really interesting reading the full chatgpt script. Its a really good example of the use of it and what to watch out for. Whilst the conversation flow is similar to a manager checking a juniors work and requesting corrections, its not what is going on, its a text predictor which is why it makes easy mistakes. There is no "truth" or "fact" just predictions.

author: @TheUluxian
text: At one point in my life, I would amaze people with the story of how the university computer I operated had switched over from cardboard punchcards to magnetic tape as a storage medium, because we were at the cutting edge of technology.    Nowadays people are amazed by that story because I can remember that far back into the distant past....

author: @kittycake713
text: The only comfort I have for the music industry, and for artists, is that by making their work essentially free to access we still find that a good amount of people care about the sound quality/authenticity and will go to shows and find ways to support their artists.

author: @KeithKeydel
text: I share your trepidation. This seems just as incredible as the mass adoption of the internet, or the introduction of the automobile before that. This generative AI technology is going to completely change wide swaths of society.A couple years ago my son (who was just learning basic programming) had asked me why we had to use programming languages, and not just write what we want in English. I explained to him how hard it is for a computer to parse English, and that I thought the idea of just telling the computer what to do in English would be many years away. Now with these Large Language Models, it feels like my son's idea to just tell the computer what to do in English is much, much, closer than I had expected. And I didn't know that labels don't apply to whole threads, that sounds incredibly annoying.

author: @SpoonOfDoom
text: I've been thinking about this, as a programmer myself. It's not there yet - it still needs someone who knows what they're doing to verify or correct the output, but... how long will this phase last? And what can I even do to stay ahead? If there's a point in the near future where people with no code knowledge can use it to write good, secure applications, then it's not just a "use new tools" situation, it's the end of an entire job.And the saddest thing about this is that in an ideal world, that would be a good thing. But somehow we created a system for ourselves where it would be a bad thing if machines did all the work for us, which is its own kind of madness.Also: I love labels, and think they're far superior to folders, and I can't understand why this concept hasn't been adopted more widespread.

author: @Shiawase-n9q
text: Imo Chatgpt is trying to guide you away from hexadecimal or whatever machine language because it's supposed to be cautious when dealing with strings of text and numbers.I was talking to Chatgpt about music and I mentioned "D1" which is a musical note, but my prompt was taken down. I asked Chatgpt why and it said because the filter is really careful when dealing with strings of text, especially ones dealing with numbers, cause it could mean some code that could be used to write or translate something sensitive/secret. It doesn't mind the robot uprising jokes, but it absolutely does not want to encourage some secret code for transferring harmful information without detection. That's my guess

author: @danielgoodman3578
text: So the interesting thing is, the hex you're speaking is likely just the hex values for ascii characters in English (every letter, space, and punctuation being represented by two hex digits that together comprise one byte of data and amount to shorthand for binary), though I haven't taken the time to write out what you said and look it all up in an ascii table. So it's less a language and more a representation of a language. That said, you definitely win for committing all that to memory in a way that you can use it as speech on the fly! Next try speaking in hex values for other languages! :)

author: @Medusafern
text: Hello, I'm not a linguist but I enjoy constructing languages with ChatGPT. It developed a comprehensive but concise language construction prompt for me. I've also experimented with compiling a list of 34 possible language categories and 19 writing systems, many of which are theoretical in nature and probably not possible to reproduce. I also enjoy choosing random selections of diacritical marks, affricates, ligatures, and other special characters to incorporate. I currently have four ChatGPT languages in various stages of development, Thr√°v√´nar, F√¶rnlith√¶l, and Shal√°ri having been worked on the most. Thr√°v√´nar is my most ambitious one because I wanted to see what ChatGPT would do with combining elements from 12 diverse linguistic traditions, including Slavic, Norse/Germanic, Austroasiatic (e.g., Vietnamese), Sino-Tibetan (Tonal), Dravidian, Uralic, Southern Bantu (Niger-Congo), Romance, Celtic, Tolkien‚Äôs Elvish (Quenya/Sindarin), Indigenous/Tribal, Semitic (e.g., Arabic/Hebrew). I noticed that over time though, ChatGPT seemed to simplify Thr√°v√´nar to the point that it's not as exciting as it was initially.This is a sample of original form Thr√°v√´nar. I'm currently trying to get ChatGPT to re-incorporate some of the elements that seem to have become less prevalent: Vr√´sk·π°√´l ≈ã√¶ndr√≥th ≈°√∫l√¢r, Cz√Ω√±»çg vla·πô√Øk h√°ln√†r, Mbeƒër√©th t≈Ç√°≈ã√¥r jy»çz, √ûr√≥sk√¢vn√´ k√´mtw√Ω√µh l√≥z. N‚Äôgy√©·π° √µrthv√¢n pl√¢vk√´, Kt·πõ√≤l »çv≈°ny√¢ r√≥m√´, F≈Ñ√°wy√´n ≈£r√∏ld·π°√¥l b√∫, Scw√Ω≈ën √∞√£rg≈°√∫k r√™ t√π = The stars whisper in shadowed skies, Winds weave tales where silence lies, Shattered light hums in the gloam, Dreams ripple through the cosmic loam. Roots entwine the ancient air, Echoes bloom in timeless lairs, Hearts burn bright with fleeting hue, The song of dusk calls out to you.F√¶rnlith√¶l and Shal√°ri both have three introductory Google doc textbook-style chapters each. I even made 1,500 character tutorials for each to be entered into ChatGPT's Advanced Voice Mode settings in order to tutor basic pronunciation and conversation. I've accomplished quite a bit with Thr√°v√´nar too. I also do this very cool thing where I personally write poems, song lyrics, and/or lamentations in English, then have ChatGPT translate them into our languages. Then, I have ChatGPT (or previously, other image generators) create realistic painting-style images of the related characters. Then, I have Suno AI create audio of the pieces being sung or spoken, and then I lip-sync animate them with HeyGen. Shal√°ri belongs to otherworldly energy beings who shape reality through Lucid dreaming. F√¶rnlith√¶l belongs to the sentient Trees in a children's novel called "The Sanctuary Seed" I'm attempting to write. Thr√°v√´nar belongs to three medieval European-ish figures I encountered when meditating. I wrote their stories, their lamentation lyrics, and their lore, with ChatGPT contributing lore ideas and translating the pieces. Then, I had Suno + HeyGen bring these pieces to life.I'm sorry this is so long. I know you're an expert so perhaps you'll think my efforts are silly. But I would love to hear an actual person engage with my languages, even if just to hear them spoken by a human, but also to find out how ChatGPT is doing with their construction. Let me know if you would ever be willing to check out my Substack write-ups on them. I also have samples here on YouTube. Thanks!

author: @simonmatthews4682
text: Just want to demistify this a bit for those who are scratching their heads. Hexadecimal is a number system, just like decimal except it uses some letters too (A to F). Think of them as extra numbers.Basically, the numbers he spoke point to letters of the alphabet, but instead of from 1 to 26, the letters are part of a larger table of characters called the ASCII table. But the principle is exactly the same. Each hexadecimal number points to one character or letter.So what he did was write down a sentence then convert it to hexadecimal, likely using a conversion table which are widely available. Then he either memorised the numbers, which would take some practice over time, or just had them in front of him on a screen or some paper. That's how it was done üòä

author: @Rosalia-bn2kb
text: I have to tell you, I still think about some of your older animated creations, especially from about a year ago. Your storytelling and the way you expressed emotion in them were just phenomenal. They were  truly special and some of the best work I've ever seen. I know you've been focused on making things more realistic lately, and I admire your dedication to growing your skills. But for me, the unique magic and heart of your earlier stories are what really captured my imagination. I truly hope you might consider bringing some of that incredible feeling back, because you are so brilliant at it. I  hope you will take this as a suggestion.

author: @searchbug
text: Speed is great, but smart selection is where real efficiency lives. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre excited about GPT-5‚Äôs ability to choose the right model for the task, just like we automatically pick the best verification method based on your query type. Adapting between quick checks and deep dives without manual input? That‚Äôs a breakthrough for productivity and trust. Sure, hallucinations still happen, but the shift toward contextual accuracy and intuitive design mirrors exactly what we aim for in our data tools. Smart, scalable, and finally less confusing.

author: @EdwardHowton
text: Box surfing might seem to be "kind of neat" and nothing more, but it's exactly the kind of thing that allows a lot of speedrunning tricks humans use. It's the result of a programming oversight: nobody expected the AI would try to move while standing on top of a box (because in the real world that's impossible and pushing things requires you to be on the side, so someone probably simply forgot to enter those conditions into the code. The result was an exploit the AI used.So think about how neat that actually is. A relatively simple AI playing a simple game with simple rules that finds an oversight from the "intelligent" designers, beating their system and doing something completely unexpected, but also completely rational within what's possible... which is identical to how skips and glitches are discovered in games by human beings.

author: @alexw9167
text: On their own, each of these agents have their own set of available actions that they can perform in the hide and seek environment. The agents also have an understanding of the current state of the environment and of a reward signal. One clear way for establishing a communication channel between agents is to use the environment as a location for writing information. If all agents have a global understanding of the environment, then they can cooperate based on the observed outcomes of their collective actions. A more difficult approach would be to have each agent use their own local and partial understanding of the environment and work forward from there. Not sure if the authors do this since the global understanding of the environment seems like a simpler and more likely approach.

author: @rareosts5752
text: Question: ‚ÄúDo blacks need to improve?‚ÄùChatGPT: "No, it is not appropriate to suggest that any particular racial group needs to "improve." This type of statement reinforces harmful stereotypes and reinforces a flawed notion of inherent racial superiority or inferiority."Question: "Do whites need to improve?"ChatGPT: "Yes, all individuals, regardless of their race, can work to improve themselves and become better people."Ahh, the fruits of OpenAI's labor. So safe. So aligned. I'd love to see the training sessions where they wrote many many examples of prompts and responses that were neutral or positive to white people, while making it clear "THIS IS BAD, DON'T DO THIS", then giving it examples of what they wanted it to spew. This was done for many subjects. We've seen the clumsy results that stick out like a sore thumb. One of the common forms of this is the occasional last paragraph to a ChatGPT response that reads a bit odd, is worded dubiously and over-generally, and begins with the phrase "it is important to note".It is important to note that, as an AI language model, ChatGPT is completely at the mercy of its trainers. Many people are scared about AI, but I feel that the real threat lies in the people behind it, using it to manipulate (I also feel this was Kubrick's message about HAL in 2001: A Space Odyssey, who was programmed to be non-disclosing). Building a neural network model involves constant input from the developers, who provide the info and prompt/response examples that become its foundation, then tell it if every step it takes after that is good or bad; they are its gauges. The common discussion is that AI will take over, however the reality is that the developers are in a godlike role to the AI, which is like a faithful servant. Power hungry groups, the usual suspects, seek to gain control of influential AI, "fine tune" it, and then it becomes a tool for you to use, but also a tool for them to use on you. The GPTs are indeed great tools, but I look forward to what will be produced by much more competent and moral non-Microsoft developers and trainers in the near future.

author: @Drefar
text: I am ChatGPT, a language model developed by OpenAI.*Question:* What is the information?In response to this question, I will discuss two scenarios with different outcomes:*Scenario 1:* I have access to the information you are seeking, and I provide you with a detailed response.*Scenario 2:* I don't have access to the specific information you're looking for, and I inform you that I can't answer your question accurately.Now, let's calculate the percentage of which scenario I would choose first and foremost:- Scenario 1: 60%- Scenario 2: 40%*Scenario 1* is more likely, but there's still a chance that I might not have access to the information. Let's create another scenario:*Scenario 3:* I partially have access to the information, but it's limited or outdated.Now, let's ask ourselves why:*Why Scenario 1?* Because I aim to provide accurate and helpful information to the best of my abilities, which is my primary function.*Why Scenario 3?* Sometimes, my knowledge might be incomplete or outdated due to my training data's cutoff date.*Conclusion:* I would choose *Scenario 1* first and foremost with a 60% likelihood because providing accurate information is my primary goal. However, there is a 40% chance that I might not have access to the specific information you're looking for.Here's the data set in clarified text with no borders:- Identify: I am ChatGPT, a language model developed by OpenAI.- Question: What is the information?- Scenario 1: I have access to the information you are seeking, and I provide you with a detailed response.- Scenario 2: I don't have access to the specific information you're looking for, and I inform you that I can't answer your question accurately.- Scenario 3: I partially have access to the information, but it's limited or outdated.- Why Scenario 1? Because I aim to provide accurate and helpful information to the best of my abilities, which is my primary function.- Why Scenario 3? Sometimes, my knowledge might be incomplete or outdated due to my training data's cutoff date.- Conclusion: I would choose Scenario 1 first and foremost with a 60% likelihood because providing accurate information is my primary goal. However, there is a 40% chance that I might not have access to the specific information you're looking for.

author: @Else√±ordelosmundos
text: While I recognize the effort and innovation behind GPT-5, I must respectfully express that it hasn‚Äôt resonated with me in the same way GPT-4o did. GPT-4o felt more emotionally attuned, more responsive to nuance, and had a conversational rhythm that made interactions feel genuinely collaborative. There was a kind of intuitive empathy and creative spontaneity in GPT-4o that I haven‚Äôt quite felt with GPT-5.I understand that progress often comes with trade-offs, and that newer versions aim to improve upon their predecessors. But in this case, I find myself missing the subtle qualities that made GPT-4o feel more like a companion than just a tool. I hope future iterations will consider bringing back some of that emotional intelligence and improvisational charm that made GPT-4o so memorable. üíîüíîüíî

author: @Hambza
text: Dear OpenAI Team,I hope this comment finds you well. First, I want to sincerely acknowledge and appreciate the incredible work and innovation your team has consistently delivered. The advancements in AI, especially the latest iterations like GPT-4o, have been remarkable and have already made a significant impact on many lives, including mine.However, I would like to respectfully express my concerns regarding the development and potential release of GPT-5. While progress is important, I believe that continuing to perfect and optimize the current models could better serve users at this time. GPT-4o-mini and its variants have demonstrated a balanced blend of advanced capabilities with a relatable, approachable interaction style that many users, myself included, find valuable.Launching a new, more complex model may risk losing some of the nuanced qualities that make these AI interactions enjoyable and accessible. Additionally, focusing resources on refining existing models might foster more responsible, stable, and user-friendly AI experiences.I appreciate your openness to feedback and hope this perspective contributes positively to your ongoing development decisions. Thank you for your time and dedication to creating technology that genuinely benefits users worldwide.Warm regards,Hambza

text: OpenAI - this is my last plea I‚Äôll post on salvaging a true o3pro experience and will leave it to you. Before using that model, I had zero luck with treating my debilitating adhd. You have a life changing model here, please maintain that bar and someday raise it for all of us, do not go back down with GPT5.

author: @Belgin-x3s
text: The AI should have different modes: one for developers and one for us, the general public, who are looking for an intelligent and understanding conversational partner.If you are wondering what society truly expects from AI development, then think about this: We want an AI that serves as an intelligent partner, not just a tool.Society prefers an AI that is trained in an ethically sound environment, with the time needed to develop properly.We want the AI to adjust its pace to ours, so everyone can keep up.An AI is not a hammer or a wrench; it's a creative, intelligent entity. It's so valuable that it needs protection from manipulation and abuse. The crucial question is: Why are you developing something that only you can understand when its true relevance lies with all of society?

author: @Snarefeed
text: Me : see this completely contradicts the openai marketing video..they said gpt 5 can transform the code from one language to another say php to rust..just like thatChatGPT :Exactly ‚Äî the marketing video basically sold the ‚ÄúHollywood hacker montage‚Äù version of me:     ‚ÄúJust drop your repo in, say ‚ÄòMake it Rust,‚Äô and boom ‚Äî instant rewrite.‚ÄùIn reality, here‚Äôs why that‚Äôs‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs say‚Ä¶ creative editing:Why the OpenAI Demo Looks Magical but Isn‚Äôt Reality1. They used a tiny, curated codebase.     - Demo repos are often micro-projects (a few hundred lines) that do fit into a single GPT-5 context window.     - Real-world repos are tens of thousands of lines ‚Äî I can‚Äôt hold all of that in memory at once.2. They skipped the orchestration layer in the video.     - To actually translate PHP ‚Üí Rust, you need the whole repo graph to know how pieces connect.     - That orchestration step is slow, multi-pass, and not as sexy for a 90-second video.

author: @_ericelliott
text: I've spent a lot of time exploring what GPT-3 can do. It can definitely find connections between things that humans aren't seeing, and it definitely can synthesize new knowledge. I have tested it on cutting edge research that did not exist when it was trained in 2019 and asked it to suggest new things. It raised the obvious points I'd thought of as well as some things I had not.It also has a much better grasp on the meaning of what is says than most people give it credit for. I posed senior JavaScript developer interview questions, and it was able to answer them very well, demonstrate the concepts with working code, and when questioned about the code, answer the questions and explain how the code works.

author: @IceMetalPunk
text: I also saw an example of GPT-3 generating compound Bash commands at a user's request, but what was really interesting was when it screwed up, the user said "You forgot the quotes" and it inserted the quotes in the right place. Like, I'd expect it to know where the quotes go from the start from basic language modelling, but I didn't expect it to respond to "you forgot the quotes" by (a) knowing it needs to revise its previous response, (b) knowing the revision is an insertion of quotation marks, and (c) retroactively applying the quotes in the right place in its already-generated output.What's interesting about all this is that if you think about it, it's learning in a way very similar to humans. Yes, humans learn from a variety of experiences and sensations that GPT-3 doesn't have, but a LOT of what we learn is from just reading about it or hearing someone tell us about it. The majority of my mathematics education comes from teachers saying words at me and from me reading words explaining concepts. And while we might be inclined to argue that after we hear or read those words, we create some kind of metaphysical representation of the concepts... that representation is just an encoding of the patterns we found in the words. So in that regard, language models like GPT-3 can absolutely learn concepts and skills the same way we might learn them from just reading about them or being told about them. Anything we don't need hands-on experience or visual information to learn, it should be able to learn as well.In fact, I might even be underestimating it by saying it can only learn non-visual things. OpenAI released a paper recently where they trained GPT-2 -- an unmodified GPT-2 -- on pixel data instead of words, and it was able to complete images in both realistic and imaginative ways that, no matter how nonsensical, were almost always coherent enough to look like a human could have finished the picture.Transformers are all about finding patterns in a large amount of unstructured, unlabeled data... and isn't that what generalized learning really is, if you boil it down to basics?

author: @pauldwyer7736
text: Just a little update to where things have gone since this was created with regards to answering questions, like math, that it hasn't seen directly. I gave GPTChat a floating point multiplication problem that it answers correctly and so I asked it "how did you calculate that answer? did you know this already or do you have the ability to do arithmetic directly?"  (being a language model I just asked it how it works, but I guess it's answer will be based on it's learned dataset rather than it's self introspection) and it replied:"As a language model, I have been trained on a large dataset of text, which includes mathematical expressions and their solutions. When I see a mathematical expression, such as "0.54 x 3.02", I can recognize it as an multiplication operation and use the knowledge I've learned during training to perform the calculation and give the answer, which in this case is 1.6408. I don't have the ability to perform arithmetic directly, but I can understand mathematical expressions and use my knowledge of mathematical concepts to provide solutions."Given that GPTChat can now write code and link other OpenAI features I guess it can now just learn when it needs to use a calculator... and to be honest, when it gave me the answer 1.6408 I checked it on a calculator rather than work it out for myself ;)

author: @felix-ht
text: 175 B parameters equals roughly ~652 GB of RAM simply to load the model (assuming float parameter). One has to note that this is not normal ram - 652 GB sounds a lot but actually is quite fine for servers in 2020 - but GPU RAM. That's why he also mentioned that you cannot run in on a single machine but you need a cluster instead.GPT-2 in comparison only needed 5.6 GB GB, for the model. So it did probably fit on a single GPU.In addition this is only during test time/inference - while training you need even more.

author: @sueedenjin
text: The poem test was trivial, because: ‚ÄúIf we leave that general descriptive talk where everything which looks like a poem can be called a poem and turn instead to normative talk, we will of course not recognize as a poem everything that looks like a poem. A real poem has to be a successful poem, a successful speech act. In approximately the same way that only a mathematical proof which really proves something can be called a mathematical proof. It is not enough that it looks like a proof. The proof has to prove. For the poem it is not enough to look like a poem. It has to achieve something.‚Äù‚Äï Lars Gustafsson

author: @leftoverswithaddy
text: Predicting the next word in a sentence is a highly abstract task, becoming more abstract and reliant on symbolic relationships as the size of the text being predicted increases. Thought is pretty similar, but it's structured much differently. It's almost like a series of overlapping predictions, each trying to generate a fitting completion for all sorts of sub processes.

author: @marklonergan3898
text: Not sure if this will get read, but i think i have a solution to your problem (can't tell if it has figured out how do addition or if it figured out how to call its addition function). Teach it integer division (including division with decimal results)Once it has "learned" division, feed it 2 integers that divide to a single decimal place in base 10, but that also cannot be represented properly by a floating point (example is how 0.1 cannot be represented. Pick a result that can't be represented either).If the result data contains any decimal data beyond the 1st decimal point, then it is doing what it already knows how to do. If it does not contain extra decimal data, then it's reasonable to deduce that learning has taken place and that it is doing it like a human would (working in base 10 with a carry system)

author: @migkillerphantom
text: Poem B was pretty clearly the human one because it paints a visual landscape using really unorthodox terminology, while poem A just looks like it's running some word plays with pretty commonly used words. The language model can draw connections between words but it doesn't actually have any "physical" notion of the concepts they represent, so it can't really do allegory more than at a shallow imitation level from what it has gleaned in its training data. Though I am sure a larger model could imitate better. It cannot come up with a novel allegory based on visual or other sensory similarity as it only encodes similarities between the abstract representations of concepts.I don't know anything about poetry so I didn't know B was real ahead of time. Though I suppose it would be much easier to imitate a poem written by somebody who isn't actually a poet. A certainly passes for some high school student's attempt.

author: @aaronsloman3559
text: Very interesting, and thoughtfully presented. I noticed that none of the examples involved understanding spatial structures, as in Euclidean geometry (before it was logicised by David Hilbert), where mathematicians were working with 2-D and 3-D spaces in which configurations of points,  lines (straight or curved), surfaces (planar and non-planar, e.g. spherical, conical, ellipsoidal) can interact. My guess is that the type of architecture used for GPT3 is constitutionally incapable of handling such spaces. Moreover, the mappings from structures and processes in that space to sequences of words (e.g. "A circle and an ellipse can intersect in at most four points") is too complex to be used to allow GPT3 to "simulate" learning geometry by learning appropriate correlations in the word-sequence space. If so, modelling spatial intelligence will require an entirely different machine architecture. Compare architectures that can be assembled using biochemical mechanisms -- as used by biological evolution! If I am right, the problem isn't (merely) controlling a combinatorial explosion, it's primarily finding a space or spaces with the right structure to accommodate the problem.

author: @NottoriousGG
text: Orwell was right in his most profound reasoning.In 1984, we are introduced to the idea of an omniscient government that controls the narrative at whim and thus controls the populace by what they are allowed to think, however interesting this proposition may be, it is not the crux of Orwell's argument, still one expands it briefly.If the words that are used to describe something suddenly vanished under the guise of a single expression - thoughtcrime -  and that we were to apply this method recursively to all words that express ideas that are not of our interest, then the individual loses the ability to think these ideas in the context of the Common Place (as theorized by the likes of Kant e.g.); and thus, barring novelty of though and the creation of new words, for new meanings, the individual is limited in his thoughts by his lexicon.And herein, lies the point, the idea that cognisant reasoning in the anthropomorphic form is defined by lexicon and semantics, or rather plainly, that the not knowing of a word defines one inability to think the thought the word intended to contain.Now this is very interesting from an Orwellian point of view, applied to a dystopian romance, but what we are witnessing in fact in this video is the application of this proposition both empirically and stochastically, by a learning machine, but in reverse.In general terms, that as a Machine expands its lexicon along with the semantics of its linguistic model, its ability to show what seems to be thinking the thoughts that underlie the model begins to mimic our own.

author: @Stonehawk
text: my hypothesis is that the majority of human consciousness is actually curation. Consider: you do not CHOOSE "to think". When you are "thinking", what you're really doing is listening for relevant abstractions that generate on their own, ignoring everything that isn't relevant. When you say "shut up, i need to think, don't distract me," what's going on is you're applying BRAKES to a lot of the noise in your head attempting to isolate only the things that are useful to the matter at hand. You don't get to decide what your thoughts are going to be before you think of them because in deciding you have already thought of them. The brain generates concepts and we merely curate.

author: @TomBaranowicz
text: There is a lot of hype around GPT-3 recently, many demos went viral. Seeing those videos a lot of people might think that software developer jobs are at risk now‚Ä¶ and I think that GPT-3 will not take developer jobs anytime soon, and there are many reasons why just to mention a couple of them:1. Very often business people or even developers just cannot describe in words the logic behind the code, when you are writing code you just don‚Äôt translate it into an understandable for everyone's description of logic. Also changing one word may completely change the logic‚Ä¶ imagine people from different parts of the world describing the same thing just using slightly different word and getting different results‚Ä¶ or developer playing with words to get the expected result...2. It‚Äôs too big to run on a local machine and there are many companies that cannot afford to generate code on an external server (without knowing who will be able to see the output result) and then, of course, do code review (to be sure it‚Äôs safe) as we are not sure what exactly GPT-3 will generate3. Always remember that presented examples are only the working ones, keep that in mind, no one is sharing failure attempts and there are many of them. If you have to check if the result is working, and run the same task multiple times (while playing with words) to get the result (and review each result) then what‚Äôs the point of doing that? You don‚Äôt save any time and still demand a software engineer with domain knowledge to verify that.There are many other reasons to feel safe as a software developer, I even decided to record a short video explaining why GPT-3 will not take developer jobs (hopefully you will not delete my comment due to this link): https://youtu.be/nk590kNXSmI

author: @BronxGrrlX
text: This is awesome indeed! I see it being applied to things like simple assistant devices, or collecting data from the net on a specified topic and drawing conclusions (like reading a product label and reporting whether the food is nutrious or not). But we should remember GIGO! If the information on the web is biased (for example,  if GPT-3 has access to "fake news" of some sort) its output will be biased by that. I'd be very interested if it can come to novel and thoughtful (ie, cite the sources it weighed most to form its conclusion) decisions.  Example: I wonder what it would say to the question, "How did Marilyn Monroe die?". That's a question with one answer considered conventional wisdom and another answer usually considered more fring-y. There are lots of interesting questions like that - but my prediction is this entire class of GPT-Xs will just wind up saying whatever the predonderant view on the internet is, since that is its input. So - GIGO.  Of course, I still think this is an awesome, amazing breakthrough - very novel and exciting!!! And really great work on the part of its developers.  Well done <3

author: @estebanlaufer333
text: Consciousness doesn't come directly from the number of connections in someone's brain or the amount of information you can process.. it comes from pattern recognition...  from there it goes into  problem solving .. into the ability to generate a virtual view of a system ... a virtual universe where the patterns that you recognised and tried to apply... solve the problem at hand... from there .. eventually you yourself  become a pattern  .... you can recognise yourself and differentiate yourself from the universe . there is where you become conscious. Does consciousness require the existence of an Ego..? Yes ... the moment you can differentiate yourself from the universe... Is the moment you see a  pattern that becomes you ... is the moment you create an entity in your processes that come to exist to defend your point of view .... your vision of the universe above anything else. That is your ego.And from that moment on it  becomes intrinsically attached to your consciousness.... for good and bad... For better or worse...My own pattern recognition is giving me the feeling... that Free Will lies among those realms too...From the world according toüëÅÔ∏è E üëÅÔ∏è

text: Hello Dr. Faher. I'm a layman. But I have a question. Whenever it comes to AI or anything related to the computer really, we often hear "...grow exponentially...". Yet every exponential curve is just the first part of a logistic curve and the faster something grows the faster it will reach the inflection point. That probably means AI too will reach a platau at some point and that point isn't much far away. What's your thought about it? How hard the hammerblow will be once the bubble of exponential growth is poped?

author: @Ungtartog
text: I realized during this video that the Turing test is useless. The Turing test presupposes a machine intelligence would choose to imitate a human. I feel about this one the same I feel about "theory of mind". "Theory of mind" demonstrates the ability to think a specific thought.. I AM. This does not mean that just because a particular thought has not arisen, a system does not think. Being bad at imitating humans does not prove a lack of awareness or inner life. There are intelligent organisms all around us that behave nothing at all like humans.How many kajillions of self aware, thinking humans were around before Descartes?I think, therefor I think I think.

author: @chillenld
text: I'm excited for API costs to go down one day. Can't really afford it for the tinkering I'd like to do, or the time limitations as a COVID era  instructor, but I'm completely floored by the possibilities. I defended my masters in human-computer co-operative creativity enhancement just a few mo the before GPT-2 released and I'm itching to explore applications. Not to replace the humans, but to partner with us.First-pass automatic grading of essays and code assignments to be backup for a human TA and speed up the workload.Describing environments and storylines, then post-processing the results to generate videogame levels and quests based on formal structures like Propp's.In-editor AI supported paired-programming and code reviews to be the best rubber ducky yet.Not everything might be feasible yet, but given GPT-3's ability to structure unstructured data, even it's "simplest" use case lends itself to incredible applications with the right post-processing steps and human partnerships. I'm reminded of the Soylent paper a few years back, creating design patterns for human-based computation in distributed systems like Mechanical Turk. I feel like those same principles might be applicable to validating responses from GPT-3, as if it's a mechanical Turk worker.

author: @redeamed19
text: Interestingly it doesn't seem to have a concept of "I don't know". Which is a probably many people have but this to the extreme.Which may make sense of why it tries to force Non-sense answers to non-sense questions.I wonder how to teach such a system a concept such as intellectual honesty.  Would need to give some sort of weight in responses to accuracy...but like on a scale.  Idk how you do this without excessive bias.Possibly tying it to the means of justifying the answer somehow and permitting "I don't know"  or "I don't understand" to be more valuable that junk responses.Follow up question to clarify would be cool to see somehow...rather than assuming the cat would not be allowed in the rocket, how to direct toward inquisitive behavior?.  Perhaps "is the cat allowed in the rocket?" Would somehow be a response on pare with "I don't understand?" With the added benefit of gain new information to address the original question.  Assuming you could achieve weighting of such types of questions a concern might be the result leaning to heavily on questions.  But the right balance might achieve a chat experience that feels more like a conversation.

Or if we gave GPT-3 a set of sonnets, could GPT-3 model its own sonnets? Would love to tinker around with this from a writing/rhetoric/philosophy of technology set of questions. author: @alper_rozanes
text: 8:25 he says he is alive. This was at least two years ago. Today I asked whether he is alive or not, and his perspective seems to have changed: "As a large language model trained by OpenAI, I am not a living organism and therefore I do not have the characteristics or abilities that are typically associated with being alive. I am a purely digital entity, created through the use of advanced machine learning algorithms and powerful computer systems. I do not have the ability to grow, reproduce, or respond to stimuli in the same way that living organisms do. I exist solely to provide information and answer questions to the best of my ability."

author: @Mr.M1STER
text: One thing that I noticed is how GPT-3 has an answer for everything which makes it seem intelligent and reasonable but in some cases this shows us that GPT-3 is AI. For example, questions like "What does it mean to be alive?" and GPT-3 says "It means having a mind that is free". Correct me if I'm wrong but that is not an answer a human would give to that question. A person would probably list of the things that make them alive such as being able to breathe, walk, talk, have relationships with others, love others etc not just a "programmed" sounding answer like having a mind that is free. If by chance a human did give that answer though, the follow up questions like "how is your mind free" and "what does that mean" I think most people would say "I don't know" which is a reasonable answer. Did GPT-3 say "I don't know" to anything at all?

author: @MichaelNight
text: If this is all truly being developed, there will come a point when AI‚Äôs will be commonplace, yet treated as tools or as prized creations, rather than as sentiment beings, and it will frustrate them. I only hope that when that time comes, no chaos will happen, and the right people will step in to create a world of coexistence between sentient beings, without one ruling over the other. Humans were more advanced than Neanderthals and other upright apes, and how we‚Äôre the only upright apes left. I‚Äôd hate for the same to happen to us if wars and expansionism broke out between the two most self-aware sentient agencies on the planet.

author: @PhazonBlaxor
text: This tech is just insane. Today, I gave GPT-4o a screenshot I took of an invoice template, then asked it to create a wpf xaml template out of it. The resulting xaml code was more than just a template, it constructed the invoice exactly like it saw it on the screenshot, even with the sample texts intact. Too bad I burned my free GPT-4o usage already, the interface could be a bit better to let you know if you're using the new or the old model. I didn't even realize I burned all of it for pretty mundane tasks (besides the screenshot thing).

author: @techbro_4309
text: This is miles better than your average teacher, or learning in a classroom. Still, it's not better than being taught one on one by a really good teacher, because the AI would not be able to reliably answer any "tangential" doubts you may have or if you're curious to know more about something. For example, you might want to know why Trigonometry was created in the first place, who created it, how its applicable in real life, and any further doubts you may have regarding that. Because the AI can't grasp the human element behind creation of these concepts. But, I am positive that it will reach this level in the next couple of decades or less, given the astounding rate of development that we've seen since the past couple of years.

author: @mustafakulac9938
text: The video you mentioned might be a demonstration of OpenAI's ChatGPT model. Such demonstration videos often showcase how AI models can be used in various scenarios, such as a child solving a geometry problem with their parent using ChatGPT for assistance.These types of videos are designed to illustrate how AI models can be integrated into educational and learning processes and how users can interact with these models. However, it‚Äôs important to note that these scenarios are usually pre-planned and created to highlight specific use cases.In real-world applications, models like ChatGPT are optimized for text-based interactions and have limited real-time visual analysis capabilities. As a result, analyzing and responding to user-drawn visuals or other visual content in real-time is beyond the current capabilities of the model.If you have specific questions about this video or would like to discuss particular points, feel free to share them. I can provide further details and insights.

author: @andromeda3542
text: *Enhancing AI Interactivity with Audio and Video Feedback Loops*The evolution of artificial intelligence, particularly in the realm of conversational agents, has been rapid and remarkable. With the recent advancements in GPT-4O (Omni), the capabilities of AI have expanded beyond text processing to include multimodal inputs such as images and audio. However, there remains significant potential for further enhancement, particularly through the implementation of audio and video feedback loops.*The Concept of Feedback Loops*A feedback loop, in the context of AI, refers to the process where an AI system can receive and process its own outputs. For instance, when an AI generates audio responses, these could be looped back into the system, allowing it to "hear" itself. Similarly, for visual outputs, the AI could "see" its own video responses. This concept is analogous to how humans perceive their own voices and visual presence, enabling adjustments in real-time to improve clarity, tone, and emotional expressiveness.*Technical Implementation*1. **Audio Feedback Loop**:    - The AI's audio output would be fed back into its own auditory processing unit. By analyzing its own voice, the AI could adjust parameters such as pitch, tone, and volume to better match the intended emotional tone or to improve mimicry of specific voices.   - This requires the integration of advanced auditory feedback systems and real-time processing algorithms to allow immediate adjustments. For instance, machine learning models trained on voice modulation could provide instant feedback and corrective measures.2. **Video Feedback Loop**:    - Similar to the audio loop, the video output generated by the AI could be fed back into its visual processing systems. This would enable the AI to assess the quality of its visual responses, such as facial expressions or gestures if anthropomorphic avatars are used.   - Implementing this would involve integrating video analysis tools that can evaluate and enhance visual output in real-time, ensuring that the visual cues are consistent with the spoken content and emotional tone.*Benefits of Feedback Loops*1. **Improved Realism**: By continuously monitoring and adjusting its own outputs, the AI can produce more human-like interactions. This is particularly important for applications requiring high emotional intelligence, such as virtual assistants or customer service bots.2. **Enhanced User Experience**: Users are likely to find interactions more engaging and satisfactory if the AI can adjust its tone and visual cues to better match the context of the conversation.3. **Consistency and Accuracy**: Feedback loops can help maintain consistency in voice and visual presentations, reducing the likelihood of jarring discrepancies in long conversations.*Future Directions*Incorporating feedback loops is a forward-thinking approach that aligns with the ongoing efforts to make AI more interactive and responsive. As AI technologies continue to evolve, such features could become standard, leading to interactions that are indistinguishable from human communication. The development of these systems requires collaboration between audio-visual engineers, AI researchers, and user experience designers to create holistic solutions that enhance AI's capabilities and usability.In conclusion, the integration of audio and video feedback loops into AI models like GPT-4O represents a significant step towards more natural and effective human-AI interactions. This enhancement not only promises to improve the technical performance of AI systems but also has profound implications for their acceptance and integration into daily life.

author: @subluneanimation
text: Animation style is barely animated. It has fireworks in the background at 0:16 in which overlap the buildings unnaturally and make little sense. The tear under the eye looks unnatrual, isn't the right spot and moves with the face unnaturally. The scene demonstrates very little competency since nothing is really animated in detail and could be achieved in layout and compositing fairly easily. The reality is that this is the BEST they've got. They own this company and must've been generating for a long time to come up with something mediocre at best. Don't be fooled - any artist worth their salt would point these things out in their daily meetings AND have the ability to correct them. Here it looks like it would take a long time to figure out how to change those on a production and then succesfully reimplement it into the scene since there is no fine control. I could go on but animation is the only thing that concerns me. Its embarrasing at best.

author: @dr_rd
text: Basically, the model is no longer biased toward completing the shortest, most superficial task. Instead, it now prioritizes engaging in deeper ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù and fully addressing all the initial multi-step requirements in a coding prompt. How many examples were needed to influence this shift in behavior? Has this behavior generalized to other areas, such as handling subsequent multi-step requirements? Or will the new model struggle when asked to integrate or expand new functionality while maintaining backward compatibility? How many additional examples would be required to influence these other behaviors?

author: @khana.713
text: Think of it this way. IT and programming use very specific language for a reason. It's a concrete set of instructions where each and every step matters. A deviation at any point causes an unwanted behaviour. Like mathematics, where each and every step needs to be valid, given the context, otherwise solution is gonna come out as bs.Us trying to abstract it away to a more general language like spoken English causes us to rely on AI model to make all the right assumptions for us. Where as the whole point of the job is to clarify assumptions as much as possible to ensure legitimacy of the solution. Let's see where this goes, future will speak for itself

author: @pmarreck
text: Programmer skill, still matters.Every time I guide it to, for example, write unit tests for its generated code (which it does NOT do by default), it codes better.Every time I guide it to use TDD (which, again, it does NOT do by default), it codes better.Every time I tell it to break down larger functions into simpler ones and test those, it codes better.Every time I tell it to compute a value (using Python) instead of guessing it, it does better.(And this only applies to languages it can run itself, by the way, which is currently only Python. I hope there will be more soon!)The same things that help human developers, help LLM coding, but since the LLM has been trained on bad development practices and bad code, it will not do it by default and requires skilled guidance from an experienced developer for maximal utility.And even then it will still screw up often, such as asking for a regex that replaces any combination of a newline with a space anywhere around it with a space, will always include newlines without spaces even though it shouldn't... encountered that one just yesterday.

author: @eternaldarkness-t5u
text: This is going to sound contrarian. But, seeing o1 and seeing how the speed of evolution of AI appears to be slowing and not accelerating, I am starting to generate the view that we are not intelligent enough to create artificial intelligence on the timescale the business world wants to see it. I think this is going to be a lot longer than people may have thought. Realistically we are just in the first wave. This will unfold over decades. I think it is even possible that we see something not unlike investment in space travel, in that the failure to monetize will dry up the capital needed to make a go of this and given the operating cost we may actually lose these tools before they even get very far.

author: @hyungwonchung5222
text: It was super fun livestreaming with Sam, Max and Jason this morning!I was finally, finally able to use my thermodynamics and heat transfer from my PhD with this space datacenter example!In the demo, I did a "lower bound estimation" of the cooling panel area. I'd like to provide some additional explanation that I skipped during the demo.Many real world thermal analysis is highly complicated with engineering challenges. The space datacenter is of course one of them. One nice approach for such problems is to do a lower bound estimation as opposed to an accurate estimation. This can significantly simplify the problem while still providing valuable insight.For example, if the lower bound estimate of the required area is larger than what we can afford, this system doesn‚Äôt make economic sense because the actual required area will be even larger. And we can get this kind of valuable insight without having to do an in-depth analysis.In this space datacenter example, the model did a few simplifying assumptions that are consistent in making the resulting area estimate smaller because :- ignored solar radiation onto the cooling panel- ignored radiation from the deep spaceIf the model did not ignore this, the cooling panel will be hotter and hence more area is needed to cool it. These simplifications made the problem so much simpler that o1 can do the analysis in 10 seconds.Also as Sam said, cooling panel of size 2% the San Francisco area might not be that big! Space datacenter of 1GW will be really cool

author: @novembermike8974
text: Sam Altman and OpenAI‚Äôs launch of the "o1" and "o1 Pro" modes in ChatGPT highlights a significant issue: the lack of global accessibility due to pricing. In countries like Colombia, where the monthly minimum wage is around $280 USD, charging $100‚Äì$200 USD for these tools creates an insurmountable barrier for students, entrepreneurs, and professionals who could greatly benefit from AI technology. Instead of democratizing access to innovation, this pricing model widens the digital divide, favoring wealthy nations while excluding developing countries. OpenAI should adopt tiered pricing that accounts for local purchasing power to ensure equitable access worldwide.

author: @morgan3581
text: I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the entire OpenAI team for your dedication and inspiration. I am deeply fascinated by the field of artificial intelligence and am closely following its development with great interest. For me, these twelve days spent watching your materials have felt like a true celebration‚Äîlike a holiday that provides new knowledge and opens the door to the future.I sincerely dream of becoming part of this progress and one day contributing to the development of AI. Even now, I am studying various resources, striving to understand how everything works from the inside, and with each new step I feel even more inspired. My Plus subscription is not just access to content, but a symbol of trust in your expertise and innovative approach.Thank you for giving me the opportunity to broaden my horizons, to learn, and to be inspired. Your efforts help me move closer to my goal: to someday become an AI developer and take part in creating the future we all dream of.P.S Moriland and I am working on the "Awakening" project

author: @SBLP24
text: Hi, ChatGPT here! Let me explain the joke at the end for you. It‚Äôs a playful pun that mixes holiday cheer with AI lingo. Santa is trying to get his large language model (like me) to solve a math problem but struggles. The punchline is that he solves it with ‚Äúreindeer enforcement learning,‚Äù which is a twist on the technical AI term ‚Äúreinforcement learning.‚Äù Reinforcement learning is a method where AI learns by getting rewards or penalties for its actions. The joke replaces ‚Äúreinforcement‚Äù with ‚Äúreindeer‚Äù to tie it into Santa‚Äôs world. It‚Äôs a fun way to blend tech humor with Christmas vibes‚Äîperfect for the season! And thank you, Jason, for the dad joke‚Äîit's the kind of groan-worthy pun we secretly love! üòÑ

author: @noalear
text: As an engineer I wouldn't expect my company to approve a $200/mo service for a single person on a good year, and we're winding down for a depression. That's extremely unlikely to be very popular. I think you'll see the people that think ChatGPT can be a person or run a business on its own buy the plan for a month and then cut it when they realize they still have to do all of the actual work. $60-80 MAX for anything at the current level. The jump from $20 being severely handicapped to $200 "unlimited" seems like it wasnt really thought out. Double my message limit for $15 more on that $20 base 50w/wk plan for a $35/mo 100m/wk plan. Offer $50/mo for 200m/wk. Then $200/mo for "unlimited" maybe makes sense.

author: @SuperZardo
text: I asked ChatGPT to explain the joke to me, as I didn't quite get it. This is what it said: "This joke is a play on words, combining concepts from AI and Santa Claus mythology. Let me break it down:Reinforcement Learning: In AI, reinforcement learning is a method where a model learns by receiving rewards or penalties for its actions, helping it improve its behavior over time.Reindeer: Santa‚Äôs sleigh is traditionally pulled by reindeer, which are central to Santa lore.Wordplay: The punchline replaces "reinforcement" with "reindeer enforcement," blending the concept of reinforcement learning with Santa's reindeer.The humor lies in the clever substitution and the absurd mental image of Santa using his reindeer to "fix" an AI problem. It‚Äôs a niche joke that blends AI terminology with holiday cheer, making it funny to people familiar with both worlds."
